speaker: Martin
text: Oh, how does he always hear me?

speaker: Daphne
text: He doesn't.  He just swings through every twenty minutes. He knows you'll be eating some kind of junk.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I don't want him eating these.

speaker: Daphne
text: Well, then do what I do when I want Eddie away from me. I make a sound like [_high-pitched_] La la la la la la la la la la la!

speaker: Martin
text: That's mean!

speaker: Daphne
text: Why?  It doesn't really hurt his ears.  He just finds certain noises irritating. _Frasier and Niles enter, returning from the opera.  They are wearing tuxedoes and singing an aria - badly. Eddie dashes off to the bedrooms._

speaker: Frasier
text: That was the most riveting production of Wagner I have seen this season.

speaker: Niles
text: I still have goose bumps from when Klingsor summoned Kundry with a terrible cry and ordered her to seduce Parsifal: "Ha! Er Ist Shun Der Knabe!"

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I had a pretty good night too.  Took myself a nice, hot bath.  And, remember that corn I had on my toe?  Well, it got so soft I was just able to peel it right off.

speaker: Niles
text: Um... it's going to be difficult for me to top that, but I have some rather exciting news myself.  I'm sure you're all familiar with the Safford case that's been in the papers recently?

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, you mean that scum-sucking jerk who's trying to get his father committed?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Well, guess who's been retained by that scum-sucking jerk!  I'm going to be testifying as an expert witness at Mr. Safford's capacity hearing.

speaker: Martin
text: Wait a minute.  You're gonna help sell that poor old guy down the river?

speaker: Niles
text: Not at all.  Mr. Safford is unbalanced.  His son is worried sick about him.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, his son's worried he's not gonna get his hands on his father's fortune.  Boy, the minute a man starts getting up there his kids start making plans to divvy up his stuff.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, you'll be pleased to know that Niles and I have decided to give all your things to charity.  We're donating your clothes to the blind.

speaker: Martin
text: [_gives him a look, then:_] Well, it's just not right.  A bunch of moneygrubbers behind closed doors trying to declare this poor old guy insane.

speaker: Niles
text: For starters, it's not behind closed doors.  The entire proceeding will be broadcast on Court TV.

speaker: Martin
text: Oh, great.  What father doesn't look forward to the day he gathers his friends around the TV and says, "Hey, that's my boy.  The one making the old man cry."

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, I'm sure Niles is only doing this to protect Mr. Safford from himself.

speaker: Daphne
text: Old age doesn't have to be that way, you know.  My great-aunt Beryl lived well into her nineties, and her mind never failed her.  Of course, she lost her eyesight in her seventies, and her balance in her eighties.  By the end we spent most of our time propping her up or putting another bandage on her forehead.  Oh, but bless her heart, she could always tell you just how it happened. [_exits to the kitchen_]

speaker: Niles
text: Well, Safford is clearly irrational.  Recently, he wandered off.  They found him two days later riding across Wyoming in a boxcar full of bums; he's taken to selling off property for half its worth; and most damning of all, when I went over to evaluate him, he continually referred to me as "Sparky."

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't know, Niles, you always wanted to have a nickname. You remember your campaign to have the string section of the youth orchestra call you "Rocky?"

speaker: Niles
text: It would have worked, too, if Tilly Farraday hadn't pinned me to the ground with her trombone when I rebuked her for neglecting to clean her spit valve.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, I still think picking on the old man stinks. [_gets up and moves to the dining table to get a chip_] God help you if you're over fifty and you do anything that seems the least bit odd to your family.  _As he gets a chip, the noise of the bag once again attracts Eddie. He runs in and Martin, exasperated, screams out "La la la la la la la la la" at the top of his lungs.  The trick works, and Eddie flees the room.  Frasier and Niles, unaware of the ploy, look at Martin as if he has indeed lost his mind.  FADE OUT_  **SECOND OPINION**  _Scene Two - KACL Frasier is listening to a caller, Beth._

speaker: Beth
text: [_v.o._] And I'm pretty sure he's having an affair with his secretary.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, have you talked to your husband and heard his side of the story? [_Roz rolls her eyes_]

speaker: Beth
text: No.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, Beth, it does seem that your fears may be well-founded, but I still think you should talk to your husband before you come to any final conclusions. [_he disconnects Beth_] This is Dr. Frasier Crane, wishing you good day, and good mental health.

speaker: Roz
text: Here are those PSAs, we'll do them tomorrow before the show.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Roz. [_notices_] Roz, why is that light still on? Is that Beth who I was talking to?

speaker: Roz
text: No!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it is!

speaker: Roz
text: No, it isn't!

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, it is!

speaker: Roz
text: It is not!

speaker: Frasier
text: Have you been talking to Beth?

speaker: Roz
text: Of course not!  What do you think - I'm giving advice to your callers?  Oh, Frasier, you are so paranoid.  The world is full of enemies.  Everybody's plotting against you. [_notices a man walk in_] There's a man in a dark trench coat right behind you.

speaker: Frasier
text: Ho-ho, very droll.

speaker: Giroux
text: Dr. Crane? [_Frasier jumps_] I'm John Giroux. [_hands Frasier his card_] I work for Harlow Safford.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, Mr. Giroux, I'm afraid there's been some mistake.  It's my brother who's connected with the case.

speaker: Giroux
text: Oh, we're quite aware of that, but Mr. Safford feels he's the victim of a grave injustice.  He's an ardent fan of your show and feels you're the only man who can help him.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, that's very flattering, but given my brother's connection with the case, it wouldn't be very prudent for me to get involved.

speaker: Giroux
text: Won't you at least talk to my client?  Judge him by his words and his actions, not by how old he is?

speaker: Frasier
text: You sound like my father - a man who believes that burial is a form of age discrimination.

speaker: Giroux
text: If you stop by this evening, I'm convinced you'll find Mr. Safford is completely competent.  Even if you won't testify on his behalf, perhaps you could at least get your brother to reconsider his testimony.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's highly unlikely that I would disagree with my brother's opinion.

speaker: Giroux
text: I really admired your advice to that last caller - you know, about not judging someone until you've heard his side of the story?

speaker: Frasier
text: [_smiles_] You're a good lawyer, Mr. Giroux.

speaker: Giroux
text: Mr. Safford only seeks out the very best.

speaker: Frasier
text: I'll see you at seven?

speaker: Giroux
text: The address is on the back of my card. _Mr. Giroux leaves.  Frasier glances at the back of the card.  He then notices that Beth is still on the line and Roz is on the phone. He sneaks into Roz's booth and eavesdrops._

speaker: Roz
text: I don't care what Dr. Crane said.  You start talking to your husband and he'll start covering his tracks.  Get a detective now.  _Frasier clears his throat.  Roz quickly hangs up the phone.  She has a sheepish look as he glares at her._

speaker: Frasier
text: You were talking to my last caller.

speaker: Roz
text: I swear; it's the first and last time.  I will never do it again.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_growling_] I hope not.

speaker: Roz
text: Thanks for holding, Bill.  I'm listening. _FADE OUT  Scene Three - Harlow Safford's home. A butler ushers Frasier into the library of Mr. Safford's home. Mr. Giroux is waiting there._

speaker: Giroux
text: Enjoy your tour?

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... yes, yes.  That's quite a model railroad Mr. Safford has running through the grounds.  I've never seen one on quite that scale.

speaker: Giroux
text: Impressive, isn't it?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, yes.  Yes, especially when it's bearing down on you. I got my heels stuck in the soft grass.  I barely made the crossing.  Tell me, how often does Mr. Safford... play with his train?

speaker: Giroux
text: Just the weekends, when he gives rides to underprivileged children.

speaker: Frasier
text: Very admirable.

speaker: Giroux
text: There's a lot you don't know about him, Dr. Crane.  That's why you're here.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, well, I promise to consider all the evidence before I arrive at a conclusion.  _Suddenly, he hears someone shout "Yee-haw!"  Frasier turns to see an elderly gentleman sliding down a fire pole.  He is impeccably dressed, except for the fireman's hat on his head._

speaker: Frasier
text: I think I've arrived. [_Mr. Giroux leaves_]

speaker: Harlow
text: Hiya, Sparky.  I'm Harlow Safford.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Frasier Crane.  I don't believe I've ever seen a fire pole in a home before.

speaker: Harlow
text: Oh, it saves a lot of time.  Except for going up, of course.

speaker: Frasier
text: And, uh, the hat?

speaker: Harlow
text: Oh, it's just for laughs.  Oh, try it on.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, no, I don't think I should.

speaker: Harlow
text: Oh, come on!  _They argue for a moment until Frasier relents.  He puts it on and stands proudly._

speaker: Frasier
text: I guess it is sort of fun, isn't it?

speaker: Harlow
text: Not on you. [_he takes it off Frasier_] So, do you think you can convince my self-righteous son that I'm not nuts?

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I think "nuts" is a little strong.  He must have meant that your behavior might seem to most people to be a little unconventional.

speaker: Harlow
text: Well, good.  I've spent my whole life being conventional. Then one day I said to myself, "Harlow, you're not having any fun."

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you... speak to yourself often?

speaker: Harlow
text: Don't try to trip me up, Sparky. [_he walks over to Frasier, carrying a cigar box_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, no, thank you.  Thank you, I'm trying to cut down on... [_notices what's really in the box_] lollipops.  Thank you. [_takes a handful_] But tell me, why do you call people "Sparky"?

speaker: Harlow
text: It makes them smile.  Right, Sparky? [_Frasier smiles_] You ought to try it with your patients.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, I'm not too sure how warmly that would be embraced by those undergoing electroshock.

speaker: Frasier
text: Um, anyway, your son tells me that you recently sold some property at a fraction of its value.

speaker: Harlow
text: That's right.  Terrific young married couple had their hearts set on it, but couldn't afford it.  So, I helped them out. There's nothing wrong with helping people.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, he also informed me that you recently indulged in an unorthodox, not to mention hazardous mode of travel.

speaker: Harlow
text: That pompous weenie.  That's exactly how he would put it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, actually, that was my wording.

speaker: Harlow
text: Well, I hopped a freight.  Rode the rails.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, why not just purchase a ticket and ride in a club car?

speaker: Harlow
text: Where's the adventure in that?  I'm 78.  Someday I'll be too old to jump off a moving train!  No, you gotta live out your fantasies while you can.  Can you understand that?

speaker: Frasier
text: I think I can.  Mr. Safford, what you've said makes a great deal of sense.  Before we go on, there's something I have to ask you.

speaker: Harlow
text: Shoot.

speaker: Frasier
text: It's a little embarrassing.

speaker: Harlow
text: I can take it.

speaker: Frasier
text: Okay.  Can I slide down that pole?

speaker: Harlow
text: Follow me, Sparky!   _End of Act One  Act Two_  **IF I HAD ONLY WORN MY COTTON CHINOS**  _Scene One - Frasier's apartment. Later that evening.  Daphne is clearing the table.  Frasier is reading at the couch while Martin gets ready to watch TV._

speaker: Frasier
text: Dad, are you going to watch something now?

speaker: Martin
text: Yeah, the championship fight.  But don't worry, I'm using my earphones, I won't bother anyone.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, you've already been a bother - making me hide the sports section so he won't see it.  Making me turn the news off because they might say who won.

speaker: Frasier
text: I don't understand.

speaker: Martin
text: Well, the fight was last night.  It was on Pay TV.  But one of my police buddies has a pirate antenna.  So, he taped it and they messengered one to me in an envelope marked "Official Business."

speaker: Frasier
text: Another inspiring tale of our men in law enforcement.

speaker: Martin
text: [_putting on his headphones_] Why are you walking funny?

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, suffice it to say I learned today it is unwise to slide repeatedly down a fire pole wearing woolen trousers. [_the doorbell rings_] Daphne, would you...?

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, I'll get it.

speaker: Niles
text: Evening, Daphne.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh, Dr. Crane, don't say anything about last night's boxing match.  Your dad hasn't seen it yet.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, I didn't even know it was boxing season. [_Daphne just smiles_] Well, did everyone see my mention in this morning's paper?

speaker: Frasier
text: No, I'm afraid I missed that.

speaker: Niles
text: Well, small wonder.  They buried it all the way back on page 32.  It's here, it's next to the sports section.

speaker: Martin
text: [_batting the paper out of Niles's hands_] Hey, get that out of here!

speaker: Daphne
text: [_catches the paper_] Let me see.

speaker: Niles
text: It's right there.

speaker: Daphne
text: Oh. [_reading_] "Court TV this week will feature the capacity hearing of noted timber baron Harlow Safford. [_Martin glares at Niles_] Testifying on behalf of the family will be Dr. Niles Crane, eminent psychiatrist, author and leading authority on clinical psychosis.  Dr. Crane is also the brother of..."

speaker: Niles
text: Yadda-yadda, the rest is filler.

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I have to talk to you about something.  Just after the show today I was visited by a man named Mr. Giroux. He asked me to represent Mr. Safford.

speaker: Niles
text: [_standing_] What?!

speaker: Martin
text: Shh!

speaker: Frasier
text: [_pulling Niles down_] I'm sorry.  Given your involvement with the case, I naturally declined.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, thank God.

speaker: Frasier
text: But, I did agree to see if I concurred with your analysis and speak to Mr. Safford.

speaker: Niles
text: [_again standing_] What?!

speaker: Martin
text: Hey, keep it down!

speaker: Frasier
text: I just have to tell you that I found Harlow Safford to be of completely sound mind - and don't say "What?!"

speaker: Niles
text: [_struggles_] Why?!

speaker: Martin
text: Quiet!!

speaker: Frasier
text: Perhaps it'd be better if we spoke somewhere else.

speaker: Niles
text: You couldn't stand that I had a high-profile case, could you?  So you had to butt into it!

speaker: Frasier
text: I just don't want you to make a fool of yourself.  These people came to me, they asked for my expertise.

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, ha!  They were undoubtedly exploiting your dubious celebrity.

speaker: Frasier
text: Of which you are jealous and, I fear, the reason you took this case!

speaker: Niles
text: That is flatly untrue!  I took the case to help the family!

speaker: Frasier
text: And to be on television!

speaker: Niles
text: I don't give a hoot about television!

speaker: Martin
text: [_shouting_] Well, some of us do!!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, you made a hasty judgment and I am sorry, but you were wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Ah, now we see why you got involved in the case - so big brother could be right and little Niles could be wrong, which I'm not!

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, your pathetic childhood issues have nothing to do with it. Face it, you were wrong!  Wrong, wrong, wrong!

speaker: Niles
text: Oh, oh, oh-! _Frasier exits to the kitchen.  Niles, outraged, follows him.  Daphne is there listening to the radio while she cleans._

speaker: Niles
text: This from Mr. Quick-Fix, the master of the in-depth, one- minute phone call diagnosis!

speaker: Frasier
text: I spent several hours with Mr. Safford and I found his behavior to be...

speaker: Niles
text: Wildly irrational.  He's a lip-diddling loon!

speaker: Frasier
text: You think anything that's even slightly spontaneous is aberrant.

speaker: Niles
text: That's ridiculous!  The man's incompetent!

speaker: Frasier
text: Niles, I'm warning you.  If you get up in that courtroom and say that, you will damage yourself professionally!

speaker: Niles
text: I'm testifying, and you're not going to stop me!

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine, then you leave me no choice but to testify against you!

speaker: Niles
text: Well, in that case, I'll see you in court!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good, I look forward to it!

speaker: Niles
text: So do I!

speaker: Frasier
text: Good!

speaker: Niles
text: Good!

speaker: Martin
text: [_entering from the living room_] HEY!!

speaker: Frasier
text: Daphne, please.  Turn down that radio. Dad is trying to watch a fight!  _The men exit, leaving Daphne stunned.  FADE TO:_  **ANOTHER REASON TO KEEP CAMERAS OUT OF THE COURTROOM**  _Scene Two - the courtroom. The proceedings have not yet begun.  The Court TV camera is being set up.  Frasier is chatting with Mr. Safford._

speaker: Frasier
text: So, how are you holding up?

speaker: Harlow
text: Oh, I'm fine.  Now look, Sparky.  I know you don't want to take any money for helping me.  But at least let me make a donation to your favorite charity.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well... it was my duty, not to mention a pleasure, to help you.  But if you'd like to donate something, why don't you select a charity of your own choosing?

speaker: Harlow
text: Fair enough.

speaker: Frasier
text: Good.  Excuse me.  _He walks over to where Niles is seated.  Niles is primping in front of a mirror._

speaker: Frasier
text: Hello, Niles.  You know, it's not to late to ask them to put a big blue ball in front of your face during the broadcast. Perhaps spare you some shred of your reputation.

speaker: Niles
text: I'd laugh in your face but I'm saving my voice. [_clears throat_]

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh my God!  You're wearing makeup!

speaker: Niles
text: I am not!  This is... medication.  Something my dermatologist recommended.

speaker: Frasier
text: Dr. Revlon?

speaker: Niles
text: [_standing up_] These feeble attempts to undermine my confidence are futile.  The testimony I've prepared is nothing short of brilliant.  I cite half a dozen studies of gerontology.  I quote everything from the Bible to Herodotus.  I deftly interweave humor with pathos.  You may want to take notes.

speaker: Frasier
text: And if you had an ounce of self-awareness you would realize that your diagnosis was colored by your zeal to put your face in front of that camera. [_Niles scoffs_] Oh, by the way, your medication is rubbing off on your collar.

speaker: Baliff
text: All rise.  Court is in session.  Judge Richard McCarron presiding.

speaker: Niles
text: [_facing camera_] Hello, your honor.

speaker: Judge
text: Be seated.  Good morning.  Has everyone been sworn in?

speaker: Baliff
text: Yes, your honor.

speaker: Judge
text: Well, I see we have two Dr. Cranes testifying today. [_Niles stands, then sits back down._] Mr. Giroux, I think we'll hear from your authority first.  I assume the other Dr. Crane has no objection to that arrangement?

speaker: Niles
text: [_facing camera_] None whatsoever, your honor.

speaker: Judge
text: I'm over here, Dr. Crane.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_standing_] Your honor, I would not presume to bore the court with a recitation of dry statistics, gerontology studies, obscure literary references.  _He stands in such a way that Niles is blocked from the camera. Niles moves his head back and forth trying to get a clear shot of himself on TV._

speaker: Frasier
text: Instead, I intend to speak from the heart.  I worry about a society that has chosen to define normalcy in such narrow terms that if someone's behavior deviates ever so slightly, we question his capacity to function.  Mr. Safford's seeming eccentricities - his love of trains, his generosity - they can all be readily explained.

speaker: Harlow
text: Diabetes!

speaker: Judge
text: Mr. Safford?

speaker: Harlow
text: I was talking to Sparky.

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... [_to Mr. Safford_] Did you say diabetes?

speaker: Harlow
text: Yes.  We'll donate the money to diabetes.  Those poor people can't eat sugar!

speaker: Frasier
text: Fine.. fine.  Uh... we'll, uh... we'll talk about it afterwards.

speaker: Judge
text: May we continue, Dr. Crane?

speaker: Frasier
text: My apologies, your honor.  Mr. Safford and I were discussing a very sizable donation he intends to make later today to a very worthy cause.  I guess his enthusiasm just got the best of him.  But, it is this very generosity that his son finds so objectionable.  That, and the fact that he did hop a freight train across the country.  But, you see, what he sees as unstable, I see as... romantic.

speaker: Frasier
text: I... I don't suppose there's a railroad track outside the courtroom?  _The judge shakes his head no.  Cut to Harlow blowing a whistle, much to the embarrassment of Mr. Giroux.  Everyone in the courtroom begins eyeing Mr. Safford strangely.  Frasier becomes increasingly agitated._

speaker: Frasier
text: Uh... doesn't Mr. Safford deserve to be a bit of a free spirit after the years of his demanding career?  A career in which he wore... [_Harlow puts on a conductor's hat_] many hats.  Um... the hat of a father, a philanthropist, a C.E.O...

speaker: Harlow
text: All aboard!  All aboard!  Get your tickets ready.  Have your tickets ready, please.  Have your tickets ready.  _Harlow stands up and produces a hole punch, with which he begins to punch holes in papers as if he were a train conductor._

speaker: Frasier
text: [_desperate_] In the end, it all comes down to this: can we really condemn a man for maintaining a childlike _joie de vivre_ even in his twilight years?

speaker: Harlow
text: All aboard for the Coast Express.  Yes, making stops in Tacoma, Olympia, Portland and Salem.  And the next stop is...

speaker: Frasier
text: [_putting his arm around Harlow_] I think I know where your next stop is going to be. _FADE TO:  Scene Three - the courtroom. The courtroom is empty, save a very sullen Frasier.  Niles walks in. He, too, appears downcast._

speaker: Frasier
text: Now, look, Niles.  Before you start gloating, let me just say this.  You were right, I was wrong.

speaker: Niles
text: Big deal.  The world never got a chance to hear me be right. I suppose by now it's obvious that what you were saying all along was true.  I do... envy your fame.  Well, perhaps this public humiliation will cure me of my damned competitiveness.

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, don't worry about it.  I humiliated myself far more than you did today.

speaker: Niles
text: Obviously, you didn't see the way I was whoring after that TV camera.

speaker: Frasier
text: Obviously, you didn't see how I was tap dancing up there like an organ grinder's monkey.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, well, I might as well have been tarred and feathered.

speaker: Frasier
text: I might as well have been pilloried in the town square.

speaker: Niles
text: I might as well have been stripped naked and forced to...

speaker: Frasier
text: Oh, stop it, Niles!  We're doing it again!  Niles, you have no reason to feel badly.  Everyone wants to be recognized for something they're good at.  And you are a good psychiatrist.

speaker: Niles
text: Thank you, Frasier.

speaker: Frasier
text: Something I can't really lay claim to after today.  How could I have so misjudged that man?

speaker: Niles
text: Well, he's undeniably charming for one thing.  And he can be lucid for long stretches of time.

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes, but you weren't fooled.  Somehow, you picked up on some tiny clue that I missed.  You remember what it was?

speaker: Niles
text: Yes.  Midway through our interview he took off his trousers and tried to put them on the cat.

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, I'd like to think that I might have picked up on that one too.  Still...

speaker: Niles
text: Frasier, you've always approached life with a positive attitude.  It's a quality I admire of yours.  Perhaps your judgment was clouded by your desire to see old age not as a time of inevitable decline, but as a time when one's childhood passions and fantasies can be reborn.

speaker: Frasier
text: Thank you, Niles.  You know what would cheer me up right now?

speaker: Niles
text: What?

speaker: Frasier
text: I would like to hear that summation you never got a chance to give.

speaker: Niles
text: Really?

speaker: Frasier
text: Yes.

speaker: Niles
text: You're not just saying that?

speaker: Frasier
text: Do you care?

speaker: Niles
text: No!

speaker: Frasier
text: Well, all right then. [_runs to the judge's chair_] I'm the judge!  I'm the judge!

speaker: Niles
text: Okay, you be the judge.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_deep voice_] All rise.

speaker: Niles
text: Yes, here we are.

speaker: Frasier
text: [_as judge_] Have we been sworn in? [_as bailiff_] Yes we have, your honor. [_bangs gavel_] Dr. Crane, proceed.

speaker: Niles
text: Your honor, I believe it was Herodotus who said: "Circumstances rule men.  Men do not rule circumstances."  _Niles takes hold of his lapel and, looking very smug, begins his summation.  Frasier leans forward with great interest.  FADE OUT  End of Act Two_
